speaker: FORD
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: FORD
text_entry: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.

speaker: FORD
text_entry: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, and Attendants

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Draws on apace; four happy days bring in

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Another moon: but, O, methinks, how slow

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: This old moon wanes! she lingers my desires,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Like to a step-dame or a dowager

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Long withering out a young man revenue.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night;

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Four nights will quickly dream away the time;

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: And then the moon, like to a silver bow

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: New-bent in heaven, shall behold the night

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Of our solemnities.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Go, Philostrate,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Stir up the Athenian youth to merriments;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Turn melancholy forth to funerals;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The pale companion is not for our pomp.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Exit PHILOSTRATE

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Hippolyta, I woo'd thee with my sword,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And won thy love, doing thee injuries;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: But I will wed thee in another key,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: With pomp, with triumph and with revelling.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Happy be Theseus, our renowned duke!

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Thanks, good Egeus: what's the news with thee?

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Full of vexation come I, with complaint

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Against my child, my daughter Hermia.

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Stand forth, Demetrius. My noble lord,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: This man hath my consent to marry her.

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Stand forth, Lysander: and my gracious duke,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: This man hath bewitch'd the bosom of my child;

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: And interchanged love-tokens with my child:

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: With feigning voice verses of feigning love,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: And stolen the impression of her fantasy

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gawds, conceits,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats, messengers

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Of strong prevailment in unharden'd youth:

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: With cunning hast thou filch'd my daughter's heart,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Turn'd her obedience, which is due to me,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: To stubborn harshness: and, my gracious duke,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Be it so she; will not here before your grace

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Consent to marry with Demetrius,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: I beg the ancient privilege of Athens,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: As she is mine, I may dispose of her:

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Which shall be either to this gentleman

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Or to her death, according to our law

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Immediately provided in that case.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: What say you, Hermia? be advised fair maid:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To you your father should be as a god;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: One that composed your beauties, yea, and one

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To whom you are but as a form in wax

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: By him imprinted and within his power

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To leave the figure or disfigure it.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: So is Lysander.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: In himself he is;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: But in this kind, wanting your father's voice,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The other must be held the worthier.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I would my father look'd but with my eyes.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I do entreat your grace to pardon me.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I know not by what power I am made bold,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Nor how it may concern my modesty,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: In such a presence here to plead my thoughts;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: But I beseech your grace that I may know

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: The worst that may befall me in this case,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: If I refuse to wed Demetrius.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Either to die the death or to abjure

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For ever the society of men.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Know of your youth, examine well your blood,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Whether, if you yield not to your father's choice,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: You can endure the livery of a nun,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For aye to be in shady cloister mew'd,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To live a barren sister all your life,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Chanting faint hymns to the cold fruitless moon.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Thrice-blessed they that master so their blood,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To undergo such maiden pilgrimage;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: But earthlier happy is the rose distill'd,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Than that which withering on the virgin thorn

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Grows, lives and dies in single blessedness.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: So will I grow, so live, so die, my lord,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Ere I will my virgin patent up

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Unto his lordship, whose unwished yoke

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: My soul consents not to give sovereignty.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Take time to pause; and, by the nest new moon--

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The sealing-day betwixt my love and me,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For everlasting bond of fellowship--

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Upon that day either prepare to die

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For disobedience to your father's will,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Or on Diana's altar to protest

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For aye austerity and single life.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Relent, sweet Hermia: and, Lysander, yield

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thy crazed title to my certain right.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: You have her father's love, Demetrius;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Let me have Hermia's: do you marry him.

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Scornful Lysander! true, he hath my love,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: And what is mine my love shall render him.

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: And she is mine, and all my right of her

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: I do estate unto Demetrius.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I am, my lord, as well derived as he,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: As well possess'd; my love is more than his;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: My fortunes every way as fairly rank'd,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: If not with vantage, as Demetrius';

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And, which is more than all these boasts can be,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I am beloved of beauteous Hermia:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Why should not I then prosecute my right?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Demetrius, I'll avouch it to his head,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Made love to Nedar's daughter, Helena,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And won her soul; and she, sweet lady, dotes,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Devoutly dotes, dotes in idolatry,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Upon this spotted and inconstant man.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I must confess that I have heard so much,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: But, being over-full of self-affairs,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: My mind did lose it. But, Demetrius, come;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And come, Egeus; you shall go with me,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I have some private schooling for you both.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For you, fair Hermia, look you arm yourself

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To fit your fancies to your father's will;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Or else the law of Athens yields you up--

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Which by no means we may extenuate--

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To death, or to a vow of single life.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Come, my Hippolyta: what cheer, my love?

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Demetrius and Egeus, go along:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I must employ you in some business

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Against our nuptial and confer with you

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: With duty and desire we follow you.

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: How now, my love! why is your cheek so pale?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: How chance the roses there do fade so fast?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Belike for want of rain, which I could well

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Ay me! for aught that I could ever read,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Could ever hear by tale or history,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: The course of true love never did run smooth;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: But, either it was different in blood,--

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: O cross! too high to be enthrall'd to low.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Or else misgraffed in respect of years,--

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: O spite! too old to be engaged to young.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Or else it stood upon the choice of friends,--

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: O hell! to choose love by another's eyes.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Or, if there were a sympathy in choice,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: War, death, or sickness did lay siege to it,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Making it momentany as a sound,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Swift as a shadow, short as any dream;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Brief as the lightning in the collied night,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and earth,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And ere a man hath power to say 'Behold!'

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: The jaws of darkness do devour it up:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: So quick bright things come to confusion.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: If then true lovers have been ever cross'd,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: It stands as an edict in destiny:

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Then let us teach our trial patience,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Because it is a customary cross,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: As due to love as thoughts and dreams and sighs,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Wishes and tears, poor fancy's followers.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: A good persuasion: therefore, hear me, Hermia.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I have a widow aunt, a dowager

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Of great revenue, and she hath no child:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: From Athens is her house remote seven leagues;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And she respects me as her only son.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And to that place the sharp Athenian law

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Cannot pursue us. If thou lovest me then,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Steal forth thy father's house to-morrow night;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And in the wood, a league without the town,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Where I did meet thee once with Helena,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: To do observance to a morn of May,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: There will I stay for thee.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: My good Lysander!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I swear to thee, by Cupid's strongest bow,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: By his best arrow with the golden head,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: By the simplicity of Venus' doves,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: By that which knitteth souls and prospers loves,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And by that fire which burn'd the Carthage queen,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: When the false Troyan under sail was seen,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: By all the vows that ever men have broke,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: In number more than ever women spoke,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: In that same place thou hast appointed me,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: To-morrow truly will I meet with thee.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Keep promise, love. Look, here comes Helena.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Enter HELENA

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: God speed fair Helena! whither away?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Call you me fair? that fair again unsay.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Demetrius loves your fair: O happy fair!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Your eyes are lode-stars; and your tongue's sweet air

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: More tuneable than lark to shepherd's ear,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Sickness is catching: O, were favour so,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: My ear should catch your voice, my eye your eye,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: My tongue should catch your tongue's sweet melody.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The rest I'd give to be to you translated.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O, teach me how you look, and with what art

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I give him curses, yet he gives me love.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O that my prayers could such affection move!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: The more I hate, the more he follows me.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The more I love, the more he hateth me.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: None, but your beauty: would that fault were mine!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Take comfort: he no more shall see my face;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lysander and myself will fly this place.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Before the time I did Lysander see,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Seem'd Athens as a paradise to me:

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: O, then, what graces in my love do dwell,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: That he hath turn'd a heaven unto a hell!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Helen, to you our minds we will unfold:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: To-morrow night, when Phoebe doth behold

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Her silver visage in the watery glass,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: A time that lovers' flights doth still conceal,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Through Athens' gates have we devised to steal.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And in the wood, where often you and I

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Upon faint primrose-beds were wont to lie,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Emptying our bosoms of their counsel sweet,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: There my Lysander and myself shall meet;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And thence from Athens turn away our eyes,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: To seek new friends and stranger companies.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Farewell, sweet playfellow: pray thou for us;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And good luck grant thee thy Demetrius!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Keep word, Lysander: we must starve our sight

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: From lovers' food till morrow deep midnight.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I will, my Hermia.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Exit HERMIA

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Helena, adieu:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: As you on him, Demetrius dote on you!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: How happy some o'er other some can be!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: He will not know what all but he do know:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And as he errs, doting on Hermia's eyes,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: So I, admiring of his qualities:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Things base and vile, folding no quantity,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Love can transpose to form and dignity:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Love looks not with the eyes, but with the mind;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And therefore is wing'd Cupid painted blind:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Nor hath Love's mind of any judgement taste;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And therefore is Love said to be a child,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Because in choice he is so oft beguiled.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: As waggish boys in game themselves forswear,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: So the boy Love is perjured every where:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: For ere Demetrius look'd on Hermia's eyne,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: He hail'd down oaths that he was only mine;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: So he dissolved, and showers of oaths did melt.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I will go tell him of fair Hermia's flight:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Then to the wood will he to-morrow night

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Pursue her; and for this intelligence

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If I have thanks, it is a dear expense:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But herein mean I to enrich my pain,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To have his sight thither and back again.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Is all our company here?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: You were best to call them generally, man by man,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: according to the scrip.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Here is the scroll of every man's name, which is

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: thought fit, through all Athens, to play in our

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: interlude before the duke and the duchess, on his

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: wedding-day at night.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: to a point.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Marry, our play is, The most lamentable comedy, and

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: most cruel death of Pyramus and Thisby.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: merry. Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: actors by the scroll. Masters, spread yourselves.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Answer as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Ready. Name what part I am for, and proceed.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: What is Pyramus? a lover, or a tyrant?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: A lover, that kills himself most gallant for love.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: That will ask some tears in the true performing of

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: it: if I do it, let the audience look to their

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: eyes; I will move storms, I will condole in some

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: measure. To the rest: yet my chief humour is for a

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: tyrant: I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: tear a cat in, to make all split.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The raging rocks

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: And shivering shocks

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Shall break the locks

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Of prison gates;

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: And Phibbus' car

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Shall shine from far

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: And make and mar

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The foolish Fates.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: This was lofty! Now name the rest of the players.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: This is Ercles' vein, a tyrant's vein; a lover is

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: more condoling.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Flute, you must take Thisby on you.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: What is Thisby? a wandering knight?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Nay, faith, let me not play a woman; I have a beard coming.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: That's all one: you shall play it in a mask, and

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: you may speak as small as you will.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisby too, I'll

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: speak in a monstrous little voice. 'Thisne,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Thisne;' 'Ah, Pyramus, lover dear! thy Thisby dear,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: and lady dear!'

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: No, no; you must play Pyramus: and, Flute, you Thisby.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Well, proceed.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Robin Starveling, the tailor.

speaker: STARVELING
text_entry: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisby's mother.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Tom Snout, the tinker.

speaker: SNOUT
text_entry: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: You, Pyramus' father: myself, Thisby's father:

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Snug, the joiner; you, the lion's part: and, I

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: hope, here is a play fitted.

speaker: SNUG
text_entry: Have you the lion's part written? pray you, if it

speaker: SNUG
text_entry: be, give it me, for I am slow of study.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Let me play the lion too: I will roar, that I will

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: do any man's heart good to hear me; I will roar,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: that I will make the duke say 'Let him roar again,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: let him roar again.'

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: An you should do it too terribly, you would fright

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: the duchess and the ladies, that they would shriek;

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: and that were enough to hang us all.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: That would hang us, every mother's son.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I grant you, friends, if that you should fright the

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: ladies out of their wits, they would have no more

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: discretion but to hang us: but I will aggravate my

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: voice so that I will roar you as gently as any

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: sucking dove; I will roar you an 'twere any

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: nightingale.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: You can play no part but Pyramus; for Pyramus is a

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: sweet-faced man; a proper man, as one shall see in a

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: summer's day; a most lovely gentleman-like man:

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: therefore you must needs play Pyramus.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: to play it in?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Why, what you will.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I will discharge it in either your straw-colour

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: beard, or your French-crown-colour beard, your

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: perfect yellow.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: then you will play bare-faced. But, masters, here

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: are your parts: and I am to entreat you, request

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: you and desire you, to con them by to-morrow night;

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: and meet me in the palace wood, a mile without the

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: town, by moonlight; there will we rehearse, for if

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: we meet in the city, we shall be dogged with

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: company, and our devices known. In the meantime I

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: will draw a bill of properties, such as our play

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: wants. I pray you, fail me not.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: We will meet; and there we may rehearse most

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: obscenely and courageously. Take pains; be perfect: adieu.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: At the duke's oak we meet.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Enough; hold or cut bow-strings.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: How now, spirit! whither wander you?

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Over hill, over dale,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Thorough bush, thorough brier,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Over park, over pale,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Thorough flood, thorough fire,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: I do wander everywhere,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Swifter than the moon's sphere;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And I serve the fairy queen,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: To dew her orbs upon the green.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: The cowslips tall her pensioners be:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: In their gold coats spots you see;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Those be rubies, fairy favours,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: In those freckles live their savours:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: I must go seek some dewdrops here

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Farewell, thou lob of spirits; I'll be gone:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Our queen and all our elves come here anon.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: The king doth keep his revels here to-night:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Take heed the queen come not within his sight;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: For Oberon is passing fell and wrath,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Because that she as her attendant hath

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: A lovely boy, stolen from an Indian king;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: She never had so sweet a changeling;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And jealous Oberon would have the child

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: But she perforce withholds the loved boy,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Crowns him with flowers and makes him all her joy:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And now they never meet in grove or green,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: By fountain clear, or spangled starlight sheen,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: But, they do square, that all their elves for fear

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Creep into acorn-cups and hide them there.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Either I mistake your shape and making quite,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Call'd Robin Goodfellow: are not you he

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: That frights the maidens of the villagery;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Skim milk, and sometimes labour in the quern

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And bootless make the breathless housewife churn;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And sometime make the drink to bear no barm;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm?

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Those that Hobgoblin call you and sweet Puck,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: You do their work, and they shall have good luck:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Are not you he?

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Thou speak'st aright;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I am that merry wanderer of the night.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I jest to Oberon and make him smile

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Neighing in likeness of a filly foal:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And sometime lurk I in a gossip's bowl,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: In very likeness of a roasted crab,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And when she drinks, against her lips I bob

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And on her wither'd dewlap pour the ale.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: The wisest aunt, telling the saddest tale,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Then slip I from her bum, down topples she,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And 'tailor' cries, and falls into a cough;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And waxen in their mirth and neeze and swear

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: A merrier hour was never wasted there.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: But, room, fairy! here comes Oberon.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And here my mistress. Would that he were gone!

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: What, jealous Oberon! Fairies, skip hence:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: I have forsworn his bed and company.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Tarry, rash wanton: am not I thy lord?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Then I must be thy lady: but I know

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: When thou hast stolen away from fairy land,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And in the shape of Corin sat all day,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Playing on pipes of corn and versing love

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To amorous Phillida. Why art thou here,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Come from the farthest Steppe of India?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Your buskin'd mistress and your warrior love,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To Theseus must be wedded, and you come

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To give their bed joy and prosperity.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: How canst thou thus for shame, Titania,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Glance at my credit with Hippolyta,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: From Perigenia, whom he ravished?

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And make him with fair AEgle break his faith,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With Ariadne and Antiopa?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: These are the forgeries of jealousy:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And never, since the middle summer's spring,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Met we on hill, in dale, forest or mead,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: By paved fountain or by rushy brook,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Or in the beached margent of the sea,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: But with thy brawls thou hast disturb'd our sport.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: As in revenge, have suck'd up from the sea

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Contagious fogs; which falling in the land

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Have every pelting river made so proud

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: That they have overborne their continents:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The ox hath therefore stretch'd his yoke in vain,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Hath rotted ere his youth attain'd a beard;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The fold stands empty in the drowned field,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And crows are fatted with the murrion flock;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The nine men's morris is fill'd up with mud,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And the quaint mazes in the wanton green

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: For lack of tread are undistinguishable:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The human mortals want their winter here;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: No night is now with hymn or carol blest:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Pale in her anger, washes all the air,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: That rheumatic diseases do abound:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And thorough this distemperature we see

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Far in the fresh lap of the crimson rose,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And on old Hiems' thin and icy crown

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Is, as in mockery, set: the spring, the summer,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The childing autumn, angry winter, change

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Their wonted liveries, and the mazed world,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: By their increase, now knows not which is which:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And this same progeny of evils comes

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: From our debate, from our dissension;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: We are their parents and original.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Do you amend it then; it lies in you:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I do but beg a little changeling boy,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: To be my henchman.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Set your heart at rest:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The fairy land buys not the child of me.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: His mother was a votaress of my order:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And, in the spiced Indian air, by night,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Full often hath she gossip'd by my side,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And sat with me on Neptune's yellow sands,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Marking the embarked traders on the flood,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: When we have laugh'd to see the sails conceive

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Following,--her womb then rich with my young squire,--

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Would imitate, and sail upon the land,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To fetch me trifles, and return again,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: But she, being mortal, of that boy did die;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And for her sake do I rear up her boy,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And for her sake I will not part with him.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: How long within this wood intend you stay?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Perchance till after Theseus' wedding-day.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: If you will patiently dance in our round

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And see our moonlight revels, go with us;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Give me that boy, and I will go with thee.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Not for thy fairy kingdom. Fairies, away!

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: We shall chide downright, if I longer stay.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Exit TITANIA with her train

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Well, go thy way: thou shalt not from this grove

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Till I torment thee for this injury.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememberest

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Since once I sat upon a promontory,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And heard a mermaid on a dolphin's back

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Uttering such dulcet and harmonious breath

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: That the rude sea grew civil at her song

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And certain stars shot madly from their spheres,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: To hear the sea-maid's music.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I remember.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: That very time I saw, but thou couldst not,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Flying between the cold moon and the earth,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Cupid all arm'd: a certain aim he took

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: At a fair vestal throned by the west,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And loosed his love-shaft smartly from his bow,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But I might see young Cupid's fiery shaft

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Quench'd in the chaste beams of the watery moon,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And the imperial votaress passed on,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: In maiden meditation, fancy-free.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Yet mark'd I where the bolt of Cupid fell:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: It fell upon a little western flower,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Before milk-white, now purple with love's wound,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And maidens call it love-in-idleness.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Fetch me that flower; the herb I shew'd thee once:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: The juice of it on sleeping eye-lids laid

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Will make or man or woman madly dote

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Upon the next live creature that it sees.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Fetch me this herb; and be thou here again

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Ere the leviathan can swim a league.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I'll put a girdle round about the earth

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: In forty minutes.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Having once this juice,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I'll watch Titania when she is asleep,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And drop the liquor of it in her eyes.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: The next thing then she waking looks upon,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: On meddling monkey, or on busy ape,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: She shall pursue it with the soul of love:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And ere I take this charm from off her sight,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: As I can take it with another herb,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I'll make her render up her page to me.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But who comes here? I am invisible;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And I will overhear their conference.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Enter DEMETRIUS, HELENA, following him

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: The one I'll slay, the other slayeth me.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thou told'st me they were stolen unto this wood;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And here am I, and wode within this wood,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Because I cannot meet my Hermia.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But yet you draw not iron, for my heart

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Is true as steel: leave you your power to draw,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And I shall have no power to follow you.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Do I entice you? do I speak you fair?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Or, rather, do I not in plainest truth

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Tell you, I do not, nor I cannot love you?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And even for that do I love you the more.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The more you beat me, I will fawn on you:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Unworthy as I am, to follow you.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: What worser place can I beg in your love,--

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And yet a place of high respect with me,--

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Than to be used as you use your dog?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: For I am sick when I do look on thee.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And I am sick when I look not on you.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: You do impeach your modesty too much,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To leave the city and commit yourself

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Into the hands of one that loves you not;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To trust the opportunity of night

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And the ill counsel of a desert place

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: With the rich worth of your virginity.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Your virtue is my privilege: for that

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: It is not night when I do see your face,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Therefore I think I am not in the night;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: For you in my respect are all the world:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Then how can it be said I am alone,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When all the world is here to look on me?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I'll run from thee and hide me in the brakes,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The wildest hath not such a heart as you.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Run when you will, the story shall be changed:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Apollo flies, and Daphne holds the chase;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The dove pursues the griffin; the mild hind

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Makes speed to catch the tiger; bootless speed,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When cowardice pursues and valour flies.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I will not stay thy questions; let me go:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Or, if thou follow me, do not believe

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You do me mischief. Fie, Demetrius!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: We cannot fight for love, as men may do;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: We should be wood and were not made to woo.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exit DEMETRIUS

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I'll follow thee and make a heaven of hell,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To die upon the hand I love so well.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Fare thee well, nymph: ere he do leave this grove,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Re-enter PUCK

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Ay, there it is.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I pray thee, give it me.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I know a bank where the wild thyme blows,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Quite over-canopied with luscious woodbine,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With sweet musk-roses and with eglantine:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Lull'd in these flowers with dances and delight;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And there the snake throws her enamell'd skin,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And with the juice of this I'll streak her eyes,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And make her full of hateful fantasies.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Take thou some of it, and seek through this grove:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: A sweet Athenian lady is in love

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With a disdainful youth: anoint his eyes;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But do it when the next thing he espies

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: May be the lady: thou shalt know the man

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: By the Athenian garments he hath on.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Effect it with some care, that he may prove

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: More fond on her than she upon her love:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Fear not, my lord, your servant shall do so.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Enter TITANIA, with her train

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Come, now a roundel and a fairy song;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Then, for the third part of a minute, hence;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Some to kill cankers in the musk-rose buds,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Some war with rere-mice for their leathern wings,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To make my small elves coats, and some keep back

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The clamorous owl that nightly hoots and wonders

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: At our quaint spirits. Sing me now asleep;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Then to your offices and let me rest.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The Fairies sing

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: You spotted snakes with double tongue,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Thorny hedgehogs, be not seen;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Newts and blind-worms, do no wrong,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Come not near our fairy queen.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Philomel, with melody

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Sing in our sweet lullaby;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Lulla, lulla, lullaby, lulla, lulla, lullaby:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Never harm,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Nor spell nor charm,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Come our lovely lady nigh;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: So, good night, with lullaby.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Weaving spiders, come not here;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Hence, you long-legg'd spinners, hence!

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Beetles black, approach not near;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Worm nor snail, do no offence.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Philomel, with melody,  and c.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Hence, away! now all is well:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: One aloof stand sentinel.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Exeunt Fairies. TITANIA sleeps

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Enter OBERON and squeezes the flower on TITANIA's eyelids

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: What thou seest when thou dost wake,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Do it for thy true-love take,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Love and languish for his sake:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Be it ounce, or cat, or bear,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Pard, or boar with bristled hair,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: In thy eye that shall appear

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: When thou wakest, it is thy dear:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Wake when some vile thing is near.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Enter LYSANDER and HERMIA

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Fair love, you faint with wandering in the wood;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And to speak troth, I have forgot our way:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: We'll rest us, Hermia, if you think it good,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And tarry for the comfort of the day.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Be it so, Lysander: find you out a bed;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: For I upon this bank will rest my head.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: One turf shall serve as pillow for us both;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: One heart, one bed, two bosoms and one troth.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Nay, good Lysander; for my sake, my dear,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lie further off yet, do not lie so near.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: O, take the sense, sweet, of my innocence!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Love takes the meaning in love's conference.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I mean, that my heart unto yours is knit

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: So that but one heart we can make of it;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Two bosoms interchained with an oath;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: So then two bosoms and a single troth.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Then by your side no bed-room me deny;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: For lying so, Hermia, I do not lie.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lysander riddles very prettily:

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Now much beshrew my manners and my pride,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: If Hermia meant to say Lysander lied.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: But, gentle friend, for love and courtesy

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lie further off; in human modesty,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Such separation as may well be said

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: So far be distant; and, good night, sweet friend:

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Amen, amen, to that fair prayer, say I;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And then end life when I end loyalty!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Here is my bed: sleep give thee all his rest!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: With half that wish the wisher's eyes be press'd!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: They sleep

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Enter PUCK

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Through the forest have I gone.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: But Athenian found I none,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: On whose eyes I might approve

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: This flower's force in stirring love.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Night and silence.--Who is here?

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Weeds of Athens he doth wear:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: This is he, my master said,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Despised the Athenian maid;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And here the maiden, sleeping sound,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: On the dank and dirty ground.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Pretty soul! she durst not lie

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Near this lack-love, this kill-courtesy.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Churl, upon thy eyes I throw

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: All the power this charm doth owe.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: When thou wakest, let love forbid

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Sleep his seat on thy eyelid:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: So awake when I am gone;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: For I must now to Oberon.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Enter DEMETRIUS and HELENA, running

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I charge thee, hence, and do not haunt me thus.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O, wilt thou darkling leave me? do not so.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Stay, on thy peril: I alone will go.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O, I am out of breath in this fond chase!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: For she hath blessed and attractive eyes.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: How came her eyes so bright? Not with salt tears:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If so, my eyes are oftener wash'd than hers.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: No, no, I am as ugly as a bear;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: For beasts that meet me run away for fear:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Therefore no marvel though Demetrius

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Do, as a monster fly my presence thus.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: What wicked and dissembling glass of mine

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Made me compare with Hermia's sphery eyne?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But who is here? Lysander! on the ground!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Dead? or asleep? I see no blood, no wound.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Lysander if you live, good sir, awake.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: [Awaking]  And run through fire I will for thy sweet sake.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Transparent Helena! Nature shows art,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: That through thy bosom makes me see thy heart.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Where is Demetrius? O, how fit a word

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Is that vile name to perish on my sword!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Do not say so, Lysander; say not so

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: What though he love your Hermia? Lord, what though?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Yet Hermia still loves you: then be content.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Content with Hermia! No; I do repent

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: The tedious minutes I with her have spent.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Not Hermia but Helena I love:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Who will not change a raven for a dove?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: The will of man is by his reason sway'd;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And reason says you are the worthier maid.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Things growing are not ripe until their season

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: So I, being young, till now ripe not to reason;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And touching now the point of human skill,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Reason becomes the marshal to my will

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And leads me to your eyes, where I o'erlook

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Love's stories written in love's richest book.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Wherefore was I to this keen mockery born?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When at your hands did I deserve this scorn?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Is't not enough, is't not enough, young man,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That I did never, no, nor never can,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But you must flout my insufficiency?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: In such disdainful manner me to woo.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But fare you well: perforce I must confess

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I thought you lord of more true gentleness.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O, that a lady, of one man refused.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Should of another therefore be abused!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: She sees not Hermia. Hermia, sleep thou there:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And never mayst thou come Lysander near!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: For as a surfeit of the sweetest things

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: The deepest loathing to the stomach brings,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Or as tie heresies that men do leave

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Are hated most of those they did deceive,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: So thou, my surfeit and my heresy,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Of all be hated, but the most of me!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And, all my powers, address your love and might

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: To honour Helen and to be her knight!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: [Awaking]  Help me, Lysander, help me! do thy best

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: To pluck this crawling serpent from my breast!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Ay me, for pity! what a dream was here!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lysander, look how I do quake with fear:

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Methought a serpent eat my heart away,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And you sat smiling at his cruel pray.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lysander! what, removed? Lysander! lord!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: What, out of hearing? gone? no sound, no word?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Alack, where are you speak, an if you hear;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Speak, of all loves! I swoon almost with fear.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: No? then I well perceive you all not nigh

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Either death or you I'll find immediately.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Are we all met?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Pat, pat; and here's a marvellous convenient place

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: for our rehearsal. This green plot shall be our

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: stage, this hawthorn-brake our tiring-house; and we

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: will do it in action as we will do it before the duke.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Peter Quince,--

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: What sayest thou, bully Bottom?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Thisby that will never please. First, Pyramus must

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: draw a sword to kill himself; which the ladies

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: cannot abide. How answer you that?

speaker: SNOUT
text_entry: By'r lakin, a parlous fear.

speaker: STARVELING
text_entry: I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Not a whit: I have a device to make all well.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Write me a prologue; and let the prologue seem to

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: say, we will do no harm with our swords, and that

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Pyramus is not killed indeed; and, for the more

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: better assurance, tell them that I, Pyramus, am not

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver: this will put them

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: out of fear.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Well, we will have such a prologue; and it shall be

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: written in eight and six.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: No, make it two more; let it be written in eight and eight.

speaker: SNOUT
text_entry: Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?

speaker: STARVELING
text_entry: I fear it, I promise you.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Masters, you ought to consider with yourselves: to

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: bring in--God shield us!--a lion among ladies, is a

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: most dreadful thing; for there is not a more fearful

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: wild-fowl than your lion living; and we ought to

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: look to 't.

speaker: SNOUT
text_entry: Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: be seen through the lion's neck: and he himself

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: must speak through, saying thus, or to the same

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: defect,--'Ladies,'--or 'Fair-ladies--I would wish

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: You,'--or 'I would request you,'--or 'I would

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: entreat you,--not to fear, not to tremble: my life

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: for yours. If you think I come hither as a lion, it

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: were pity of my life: no I am no such thing; I am a

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: man as other men are;' and there indeed let him name

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: his name, and tell them plainly he is Snug the joiner.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Well it shall be so. But there is two hard things;

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: that is, to bring the moonlight into a chamber; for,

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: you know, Pyramus and Thisby meet by moonlight.

speaker: SNOUT
text_entry: Doth the moon shine that night we play our play?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: A calendar, a calendar! look in the almanac; find

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: out moonshine, find out moonshine.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Yes, it doth shine that night.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Why, then may you leave a casement of the great

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: chamber window, where we play, open, and the moon

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: may shine in at the casement.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Ay; or else one must come in with a bush of thorns

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: and a lanthorn, and say he comes to disfigure, or to

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: present, the person of Moonshine. Then, there is

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: another thing: we must have a wall in the great

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: chamber; for Pyramus and Thisby says the story, did

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: talk through the chink of a wall.

speaker: SNOUT
text_entry: You can never bring in a wall. What say you, Bottom?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Some man or other must present Wall: and let him

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: have some plaster, or some loam, or some rough-cast

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: about him, to signify wall; and let him hold his

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: fingers thus, and through that cranny shall Pyramus

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: and Thisby whisper.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: If that may be, then all is well. Come, sit  down,

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: every mother's son, and rehearse your parts.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Pyramus, you begin: when you have spoken your

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: speech, enter into that brake: and so every one

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: according to his cue.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Enter PUCK behind

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: What hempen home-spuns have we swaggering here,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: So near the cradle of the fairy queen?

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: What, a play toward! I'll be an auditor;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: An actor too, perhaps, if I see cause.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Speak, Pyramus. Thisby, stand forth.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Thisby, the flowers of odious savours sweet,--

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Odours, odours.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: --odours savours sweet:

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: So hath thy breath, my dearest Thisby dear.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: But hark, a voice! stay thou but here awhile,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: And by and by I will to thee appear.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: A stranger Pyramus than e'er played here.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Must I speak now?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Ay, marry, must you; for you must understand he goes

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: but to see a noise that he heard, and is to come again.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Most radiant Pyramus, most lily-white of hue,

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Of colour like the red rose on triumphant brier,

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Most brisky juvenal and eke most lovely Jew,

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: As true as truest horse that yet would never tire,

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: I'll meet thee, Pyramus, at Ninny's tomb.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: 'Ninus' tomb,' man: why, you must not speak that

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: yet; that you answer to Pyramus: you speak all your

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: part at once, cues and all Pyramus enter: your cue

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: is past; it is, 'never tire.'

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: O,--As true as truest horse, that yet would

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: never tire.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Re-enter PUCK, and BOTTOM with an ass's head

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: If I were fair, Thisby, I were only thine.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: O monstrous! O strange! we are haunted. Pray,

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: masters! fly, masters! Help!

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Exeunt QUINCE, SNUG, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I'll follow you, I'll lead you about a round,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Through bog, through bush, through brake, through brier:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Sometime a horse I'll be, sometime a hound,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: A hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And neigh, and bark, and grunt, and roar, and burn,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Why do they run away? this is a knavery of them to

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: make me afeard.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Re-enter SNOUT

speaker: SNOUT
text_entry: O Bottom, thou art changed! what do I see on thee?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: What do you see? you see an asshead of your own, do

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: you?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Exit SNOUT

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Re-enter QUINCE

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Bless thee, Bottom! bless thee! thou art

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: translated.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I see their knavery: this is to make an ass of me;

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: to fright me, if they could. But I will not stir

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: from this place, do what they can: I will walk up

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: and down here, and I will sing, that they shall hear

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I am not afraid.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Sings

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The ousel cock so black of hue,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: With orange-tawny bill,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The throstle with his note so true,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The wren with little quill,--

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: [Awaking]  What angel wakes me from my flowery bed?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: [Sings]

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The finch, the sparrow and the lark,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The plain-song cuckoo gray,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Whose note full many a man doth mark,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: And dares not answer nay;--

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: for, indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: a bird? who would give a bird the lie, though he cry

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: 'cuckoo' never so?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: I pray thee, gentle mortal, sing again:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Mine ear is much enamour'd of thy note;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: So is mine eye enthralled to thy shape;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And thy fair virtue's force perforce doth move me

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: On the first view to say, to swear, I love thee.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: for that: and yet, to say the truth, reason and

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: love keep little company together now-a-days; the

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: more the pity that some honest neighbours will not

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: make them friends. Nay, I can gleek upon occasion.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Not so, neither: but if I had wit enough to get out

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: of this wood, I have enough to serve mine own turn.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Out of this wood do not desire to go:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Thou shalt remain here, whether thou wilt or no.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: I am a spirit of no common rate;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The summer still doth tend upon my state;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And I do love thee: therefore, go with me;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: I'll give thee fairies to attend on thee,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And they shall fetch thee jewels from the deep,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And sing while thou on pressed flowers dost sleep;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And I will purge thy mortal grossness so

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: That thou shalt like an airy spirit go.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Peaseblossom! Cobweb! Moth! and Mustardseed!

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED

speaker: PEASEBLOSSOM
text_entry: Ready.

speaker: COBWEB
text_entry: And I.

speaker: TITANIA

speaker: TITANIA

speaker: TITANIA

speaker: TITANIA

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To fan the moonbeams from his sleeping eyes:

speaker: TITANIA

text_entry: Hail!

speaker: MOTH

speaker: MUSTARDSEED
text_entry: Hail!

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: worship's name.

speaker: COBWEB
text_entry: Cobweb.

text_entry: I shall desire you of more acquaintance, good Master

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Cobweb: if I cut my finger, I shall make bold with

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: you. Your name, honest gentleman?

speaker: PEASEBLOSSOM
text_entry: Peaseblossom.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Master Peaseblossom, I shall desire you of more

text_entry: Mustardseed.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: that same cowardly, giant-like ox-beef hath

speaker: BOTTOM

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: you your kindred had made my eyes water ere now. I

speaker: BOTTOM

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Mustardseed.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The moon methinks looks with a watery eye;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And when she weeps, weeps every little flower,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Lamenting some enforced chastity.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Tie up my love's tongue bring him silently.

text_entry: As wild geese that the creeping fowler eye,

text_entry: Or russet-pated choughs, many in sort,

speaker: PUCK

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: thus strong,

text_entry: Now I but chide; but I should use thee worse,

text_entry: For thou, I fear, hast given me cause to curse,

text_entry: If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep,

text_entry: Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep,

text_entry: And kill me too.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: The sun was not so true unto the day

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: As he to me: would he have stolen away

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: From sleeping Hermia? I'll believe as soon

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: This whole earth may be bored and that the moon

text_entry: May through the centre creep and so displease

text_entry: It cannot be but thou hast murder'd him;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.

text_entry: So should the murder'd look, and so should I,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: What's this to my Lysander? where is he?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I had rather give his carcass to my hounds.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Out, dog! out, cur! thou drivest me past the bounds

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Of maiden's patience. Hast thou slain him, then?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Henceforth be never number'd among men!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: O, once tell true, tell true, even for my sake!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Durst thou have look'd upon him being awake,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And hast thou kill'd him sleeping? O brave touch!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Could not a worm, an adder, do so much?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: An adder did it; for with doubler tongue

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: You spend your passion on a misprised mood:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I am not guilty of Lysander's blood;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tell.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: An if I could, what should I get therefore?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: A privilege never to see me more.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And from thy hated presence part I so:

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: See me no more, whether he be dead or no.

speaker: HERMIA

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: There is no following her in this fierce vein:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Here therefore for a while I will remain.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: So sorrow's heaviness doth heavier grow

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: For debt that bankrupt sleep doth sorrow owe:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Which now in some slight measure it will pay,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: If for his tender here I make some stay.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Lies down and sleeps

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: What hast thou done? thou hast mistaken quite

text_entry: And laid the love-juice on some true-love's sight:

text_entry: Of thy misprision must perforce ensue

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Some true love turn'd and not a false turn'd true.

text_entry: Then fate o'er-rules, that, one man holding troth,

text_entry: A million fail, confounding oath on oath.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: About the wood go swifter than the wind,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And Helena of Athens look thou find:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With sighs of love, that costs the fresh blood dear:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: By some illusion see thou bring her here:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I'll charm his eyes against she do appear.

text_entry: I go, I go; look how I go,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Swifter than arrow from the Tartar's bow.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Hit with Cupid's archery,

text_entry: Sink in apple of his eye.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: When his love he doth espy,

speaker: OBERON

speaker: OBERON

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Pleading for a lover's fee.

text_entry: Shall we their fond pageant see?
