speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Why should you think that I should woo in scorn?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Scorn and derision never come in tears:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Look, when I vow, I weep; and vows so born,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: In their nativity all truth appears.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: How can these things in me seem scorn to you,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Bearing the badge of faith, to prove them true?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You do advance your cunning more and more.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When truth kills truth, O devilish-holy fray!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: These vows are Hermia's: will you give her o'er?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Weigh oath with oath, and you will nothing weigh:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Your vows to her and me, put in two scales,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Will even weigh, and both as light as tales.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I had no judgment when to her I swore.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Nor none, in my mind, now you give her o'er.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: [Awaking]  O Helena, goddess, nymph, perfect, divine!

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To what, my love, shall I compare thine eyne?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Crystal is muddy. O, how ripe in show

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thy lips, those kissing cherries, tempting grow!

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: That pure congealed white, high Taurus snow,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Fann'd with the eastern wind, turns to a crow

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: When thou hold'st up thy hand: O, let me kiss

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: This princess of pure white, this seal of bliss!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O spite! O hell! I see you all are bent

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To set against me for your merriment:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If you we re civil and knew courtesy,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You would not do me thus much injury.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Can you not hate me, as I know you do,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But you must join in souls to mock me too?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If you were men, as men you are in show,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You would not use a gentle lady so;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To vow, and swear, and superpraise my parts,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When I am sure you hate me with your hearts.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You both are rivals, and love Hermia;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And now both rivals, to mock Helena:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: A trim exploit, a manly enterprise,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To conjure tears up in a poor maid's eyes

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: With your derision! none of noble sort

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Would so offend a virgin, and extort

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: A poor soul's patience, all to make you sport.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: You are unkind, Demetrius; be not so;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: For you love Hermia; this you know I know:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And here, with all good will, with all my heart,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: In Hermia's love I yield you up my part;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And yours of Helena to me bequeath,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Whom I do love and will do till my death.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Never did mockers waste more idle breath.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Lysander, keep thy Hermia; I will none:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: If e'er I loved her, all that love is gone.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: My heart to her but as guest-wise sojourn'd,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And now to Helen is it home return'd,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: There to remain.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Helen, it is not so.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Disparage not the faith thou dost not know,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Lest, to thy peril, thou aby it dear.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Look, where thy love comes; yonder is thy dear.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Re-enter HERMIA

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Dark night, that from the eye his function takes,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: The ear more quick of apprehension makes;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Wherein it doth impair the seeing sense,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: It pays the hearing double recompense.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Why should he stay, whom love doth press to go?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: What love could press Lysander from my side?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Lysander's love, that would not let him bide,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Fair Helena, who more engilds the night

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Than all you fiery oes and eyes of light.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Why seek'st thou me? could not this make thee know,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: The hate I bear thee made me leave thee so?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: You speak not as you think: it cannot be.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Lo, she is one of this confederacy!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Now I perceive they have conjoin'd all three

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To fashion this false sport, in spite of me.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Injurious Hermia! most ungrateful maid!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Have you conspired, have you with these contrived

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To bait me with this foul derision?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Is all the counsel that we two have shared,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When we have chid the hasty-footed time

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: For parting us,--O, is it all forgot?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: All school-days' friendship, childhood innocence?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: We, Hermia, like two artificial gods,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Have with our needles created both one flower,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Both warbling of one song, both in one key,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: As if our hands, our sides, voices and minds,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Had been incorporate. So we grow together,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Like to a double cherry, seeming parted,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But yet an union in partition;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Two lovely berries moulded on one stem;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: So, with two seeming bodies, but one heart;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Two of the first, like coats in heraldry,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Due but to one and crowned with one crest.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And will you rent our ancient love asunder,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To join with men in scorning your poor friend?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: It is not friendly, 'tis not maidenly:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Though I alone do feel the injury.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I am amazed at your passionate words.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I scorn you not: it seems that you scorn me.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To follow me and praise my eyes and face?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And made your other love, Demetrius,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Who even but now did spurn me with his foot,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To call me goddess, nymph, divine and rare,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Precious, celestial? Wherefore speaks he this

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To her he hates? and wherefore doth Lysander

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Deny your love, so rich within his soul,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And tender me, forsooth, affection,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But by your setting on, by your consent?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: What thought I be not so in grace as you,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: So hung upon with love, so fortunate,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But miserable most, to love unloved?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: This you should pity rather than despise.

speaker: HERNIA
text_entry: I understand not what you mean by this.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Ay, do, persever, counterfeit sad looks,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Make mouths upon me when I turn my back;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Wink each at other; hold the sweet jest up:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If you have any pity, grace, or manners,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You would not make me such an argument.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But fare ye well: 'tis partly my own fault;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Which death or absence soon shall remedy.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Stay, gentle Helena; hear my excuse:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: My love, my life my soul, fair Helena!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O excellent!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Sweet, do not scorn her so.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: If she cannot entreat, I can compel.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Helen, I love thee; by my life, I do:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I swear by that which I will lose for thee,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: To prove him false that says I love thee not.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I say I love thee more than he can do.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: If thou say so, withdraw, and prove it too.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Quick, come!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lysander, whereto tends all this?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Away, you Ethiope!

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: No, no; he'll [        ]

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Seem to break loose; take on as you would follow,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: But yet come not: you are a tame man, go!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Hang off, thou cat, thou burr! vile thing, let loose,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Or I will shake thee from me like a serpent!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Why are you grown so rude? what change is this?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Sweet love,--

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Thy love! out, tawny Tartar, out!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Out, loathed medicine! hated potion, hence!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Do you not jest?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Yes, sooth; and so do you.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Demetrius, I will keep my word with thee.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I would I had your bond, for I perceive

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: A weak bond holds you: I'll not trust your word.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: What, should I hurt her, strike her, kill her dead?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Although I hate her, I'll not harm her so.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: What, can you do me greater harm than hate?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Hate me! wherefore? O me! what news, my love!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Am not I Hermia? are not you Lysander?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I am as fair now as I was erewhile.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Since night you loved me; yet since night you left

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: me:

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Why, then you left me--O, the gods forbid!--

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: In earnest, shall I say?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Ay, by my life;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And never did desire to see thee more.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Be certain, nothing truer; 'tis no jest

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: That I do hate thee and love Helena.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: O me! you juggler! you canker-blossom!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: You thief of love! what, have you come by night

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And stolen my love's heart from him?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Fine, i'faith!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Have you no modesty, no maiden shame,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: No touch of bashfulness? What, will you tear

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Impatient answers from my gentle tongue?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Fie, fie! you counterfeit, you puppet, you!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Puppet? why so? ay, that way goes the game.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Now I perceive that she hath made compare

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Between our statures; she hath urged her height;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And with her personage, her tall personage,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Her height, forsooth, she hath prevail'd with him.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: And are you grown so high in his esteem;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Because I am so dwarfish and so low?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: How low am I, thou painted maypole? speak;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: How low am I? I am not yet so low

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: But that my nails can reach unto thine eyes.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I pray you, though you mock me, gentlemen,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Let her not hurt me: I was never curst;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I have no gift at all in shrewishness;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I am a right maid for my cowardice:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Let her not strike me. You perhaps may think,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Because she is something lower than myself,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That I can match her.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lower! hark, again.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Good Hermia, do not be so bitter with me.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I evermore did love you, Hermia,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Did ever keep your counsels, never wrong'd you;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Save that, in love unto Demetrius,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I told him of your stealth unto this wood.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: He follow'd you; for love I follow'd him;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But he hath chid me hence and threaten'd me

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To strike me, spurn me, nay, to kill me too:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And now, so you will let me quiet go,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To Athens will I bear my folly back

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And follow you no further: let me go:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You see how simple and how fond I am.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Why, get you gone: who is't that hinders you?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: A foolish heart, that I leave here behind.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: What, with Lysander?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: With Demetrius.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Be not afraid; she shall not harm thee, Helena.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: No, sir, she shall not, though you take her part.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O, when she's angry, she is keen and shrewd!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: She was a vixen when she went to school;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And though she be but little, she is fierce.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: 'Little' again! nothing but 'low' and 'little'!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Why will you suffer her to flout me thus?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Let me come to her.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Get you gone, you dwarf;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: You minimus, of hindering knot-grass made;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: You bead, you acorn.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: You are too officious

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: In her behalf that scorns your services.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Let her alone: speak not of Helena;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Take not her part; for, if thou dost intend

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Never so little show of love to her,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thou shalt aby it.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Now she holds me not;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Now follow, if thou darest, to try whose right,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Of thine or mine, is most in Helena.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Follow! nay, I'll go with thee, cheek by jole.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Exeunt LYSANDER and DEMETRIUS

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: You, mistress, all this coil is 'long of you:

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Nay, go not back.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I will not trust you, I,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Nor longer stay in your curst company.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Your hands than mine are quicker for a fray,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: My legs are longer though, to run away.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I am amazed, and know not what to say.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: This is thy negligence: still thou mistakest,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Or else committ'st thy knaveries wilfully.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Believe me, king of shadows, I mistook.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Did not you tell me I should know the man

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: By the Athenian garment be had on?

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And so far blameless proves my enterprise,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: That I have 'nointed an Athenian's eyes;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And so far am I glad it so did sort

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: As this their jangling I esteem a sport.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Thou see'st these lovers seek a place to fight:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Hie therefore, Robin, overcast the night;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: The starry welkin cover thou anon

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With drooping fog as black as Acheron,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And lead these testy rivals so astray

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: As one come not within another's way.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Like to Lysander sometime frame thy tongue,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Then stir Demetrius up with bitter wrong;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And sometime rail thou like Demetrius;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And from each other look thou lead them thus,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Till o'er their brows death-counterfeiting sleep

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With leaden legs and batty wings doth creep:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Then crush this herb into Lysander's eye;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Whose liquor hath this virtuous property,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: To take from thence all error with his might,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And make his eyeballs roll with wonted sight.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: When they next wake, all this derision

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Shall seem a dream and fruitless vision,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And back to Athens shall the lovers wend,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With league whose date till death shall never end.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Whiles I in this affair do thee employ,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I'll to my queen and beg her Indian boy;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And then I will her charmed eye release

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: From monster's view, and all things shall be peace.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: My fairy lord, this must be done with haste,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: For night's swift dragons cut the clouds full fast,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And yonder shines Aurora's harbinger;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: At whose approach, ghosts, wandering here and there,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Troop home to churchyards: damned spirits all,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: That in crossways and floods have burial,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Already to their wormy beds are gone;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: For fear lest day should look their shames upon,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: They willfully themselves exile from light

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And must for aye consort with black-brow'd night.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But we are spirits of another sort:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I with the morning's love have oft made sport,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And, like a forester, the groves may tread,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Even till the eastern gate, all fiery-red,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Opening on Neptune with fair blessed beams,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Turns into yellow gold his salt green streams.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But, notwithstanding, haste; make no delay:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: We may effect this business yet ere day.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Up and down, up and down,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I will lead them up and down:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I am fear'd in field and town:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Goblin, lead them up and down.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Here comes one.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Re-enter LYSANDER

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Where art thou, proud Demetrius? speak thou now.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Here, villain; drawn and ready. Where art thou?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I will be with thee straight.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Follow me, then,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: To plainer ground.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exit LYSANDER, as following the voice

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Re-enter DEMETRIUS

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Lysander! speak again:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Speak! In some bush? Where dost thou hide thy head?

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Thou coward, art thou bragging to the stars,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Telling the bushes that thou look'st for wars,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And wilt not come? Come, recreant; come, thou child;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I'll whip thee with a rod: he is defiled

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: That draws a sword on thee.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Yea, art thou there?

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Follow my voice: we'll try no manhood here.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Re-enter LYSANDER

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: He goes before me and still dares me on:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: When I come where he calls, then he is gone.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: The villain is much lighter-heel'd than I:

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I follow'd fast, but faster he did fly;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: That fallen am I in dark uneven way,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And here will rest me.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Lies down

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Come, thou gentle day!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: For if but once thou show me thy grey light,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I'll find Demetrius and revenge this spite.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Sleeps

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Re-enter PUCK and DEMETRIUS

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Ho, ho, ho! Coward, why comest thou not?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Abide me, if thou darest; for well I wot

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thou runn'st before me, shifting every place,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And darest not stand, nor look me in the face.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Where art thou now?

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Come hither: I am here.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Nay, then, thou mock'st me. Thou shalt buy this dear,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: If ever I thy face by daylight see:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Now, go thy way. Faintness constraineth me

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To measure out my length on this cold bed.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: By day's approach look to be visited.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Lies down and sleeps

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Re-enter HELENA

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O weary night, O long and tedious night,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Abate thy hour! Shine comforts from the east,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That I may back to Athens by daylight,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: From these that my poor company detest:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And sleep, that sometimes shuts up sorrow's eye,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Steal me awhile from mine own company.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Lies down and sleeps

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Yet but three? Come one more;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Two of both kinds make up four.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Here she comes, curst and sad:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Cupid is a knavish lad,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Thus to make poor females mad.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Re-enter HERMIA

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Never so weary, never so in woe,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Bedabbled with the dew and torn with briers,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: I can no further crawl, no further go;

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: My legs can keep no pace with my desires.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Here will I rest me till the break of day.

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Heavens shield Lysander, if they mean a fray!

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Lies down and sleeps

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: On the ground

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Sleep sound:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I'll apply

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: To your eye,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Gentle lover, remedy.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Squeezing the juice on LYSANDER's eyes

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: When thou wakest,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Thou takest

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: True delight

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: In the sight

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Of thy former lady's eye:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And the country proverb known,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: That every man should take his own,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: In your waking shall be shown:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Jack shall have Jill;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Nought shall go ill;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: The man shall have his mare again, and all shall be well.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: lying asleep.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH,  MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Come, sit thee down upon this flowery bed,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: While I thy amiable cheeks do coy,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And stick musk-roses in thy sleek smooth head,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And kiss thy fair large ears, my gentle joy.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Where's Peaseblossom?

speaker: PEASEBLOSSOM
text_entry: Ready.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Scratch my head Peaseblossom. Where's Mounsieur Cobweb?

speaker: COBWEB
text_entry: Ready.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Mounsieur Cobweb, good mounsieur, get you your

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: weapons in your hand, and kill me a red-hipped

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: humble-bee on the top of a thistle; and, good

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: mounsieur, bring me the honey-bag. Do not fret

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: yourself too much in the action, mounsieur; and,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: good mounsieur, have a care the honey-bag break not;

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I would be loath to have you overflown with a

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: honey-bag, signior. Where's Mounsieur Mustardseed?

speaker: MUSTARDSEED
text_entry: Ready.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Give me your neaf, Mounsieur Mustardseed. Pray you,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: leave your courtesy, good mounsieur.

speaker: MUSTARDSEED
text_entry: What's your Will?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Nothing, good mounsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: to scratch. I must to the barber's, monsieur; for

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: methinks I am marvellous hairy about the face; and I

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I must scratch.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: What, wilt thou hear some music,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: my sweet love?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I have a reasonable good ear in music. Let's have

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: the tongs and the bones.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Or say, sweet love, what thou desirest to eat.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Truly, a peck of provender: I could munch your good

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: dry oats. Methinks I have a great desire to a bottle

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: of hay: good hay, sweet hay, hath no fellow.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: I have a venturous fairy that shall seek

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The squirrel's hoard, and fetch thee new nuts.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I had rather have a handful or two of dried peas.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: But, I pray you, let none of your people stir me: I

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: have an exposition of sleep come upon me.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Fairies, begone, and be all ways away.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Exeunt fairies

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: So doth the woodbine the sweet honeysuckle

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Gently entwist; the female ivy so

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Enrings the barky fingers of the elm.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: O, how I love thee! how I dote on thee!

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: They sleep

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Enter PUCK

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: [Advancing]  Welcome, good Robin.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: See'st thou this sweet sight?

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Her dotage now I do begin to pity:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: For, meeting her of late behind the wood,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Seeking sweet favours from this hateful fool,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I did upbraid her and fall out with her;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: For she his hairy temples then had rounded

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With a coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And that same dew, which sometime on the buds

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Stood now within the pretty flowerets' eyes

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: When I had at my pleasure taunted her

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And she in mild terms begg'd my patience,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I then did ask of her her changeling child;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Which straight she gave me, and her fairy sent

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: To bear him to my bower in fairy land.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And now I have the boy, I will undo

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: This hateful imperfection of her eyes:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And, gentle Puck, take this transformed scalp

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: From off the head of this Athenian swain;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: That, he awaking when the other do,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: May all to Athens back again repair

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And think no more of this night's accidents

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But as the fierce vexation of a dream.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But first I will release the fairy queen.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Be as thou wast wont to be;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: See as thou wast wont to see:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Dian's bud o'er Cupid's flower

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Hath such force and blessed power.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Now, my Titania; wake you, my sweet queen.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: My Oberon! what visions have I seen!

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Methought I was enamour'd of an ass.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: There lies your love.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: How came these things to pass?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: O, how mine eyes do loathe his visage now!

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Silence awhile. Robin, take off this head.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Titania, music call; and strike more dead

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Than common sleep of all these five the sense.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Music, ho! music, such as charmeth sleep!

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Music, still

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Now, when thou wakest, with thine

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: own fool's eyes peep.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Sound, music! Come, my queen, take hands with me,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And rock the ground whereon these sleepers be.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Now thou and I are new in amity,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And will to-morrow midnight solemnly

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Dance in Duke Theseus' house triumphantly,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And bless it to all fair prosperity:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: There shall the pairs of faithful lovers be

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Wedded, with Theseus, all in jollity.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Fairy king, attend, and mark:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I do hear the morning lark.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Then, my queen, in silence sad,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Trip we after the night's shade:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: We the globe can compass soon,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Swifter than the wandering moon.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Come, my lord, and in our flight

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Tell me how it came this night

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: That I sleeping here was found

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: With these mortals on the ground.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Horns winded within

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Go, one of you, find out the forester;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For now our observation is perform'd;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And since we have the vaward of the day,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: My love shall hear the music of my hounds.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Uncouple in the western valley; let them go:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Dispatch, I say, and find the forester.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Exit an Attendant

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: We will, fair queen, up to the mountain's top,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And mark the musical confusion

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Of hounds and echo in conjunction.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: I was with Hercules and Cadmus once,

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: When in a wood of Crete they bay'd the bear

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: With hounds of Sparta: never did I hear

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Such gallant chiding: for, besides the groves,

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: The skies, the fountains, every region near

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Seem'd all one mutual cry: I never heard

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: So flew'd, so sanded, and their heads are hung

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: With ears that sweep away the morning dew;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Crook-knee'd, and dew-lapp'd like Thessalian bulls;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Slow in pursuit, but match'd in mouth like bells,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Each under each. A cry more tuneable

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Was never holla'd to, nor cheer'd with horn,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Judge when you hear. But, soft! what nymphs are these?

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: My lord, this is my daughter here asleep;

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: And this, Lysander; this Demetrius is;

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: This Helena, old Nedar's Helena:

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: I wonder of their being here together.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: No doubt they rose up early to observe

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The rite of May, and hearing our intent,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Came here in grace our solemnity.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: But speak, Egeus; is not this the day

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: That Hermia should give answer of her choice?

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: It is, my lord.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Horns and shout within. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA wake and start up

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Good morrow, friends. Saint Valentine is past:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Begin these wood-birds but to couple now?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Pardon, my lord.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I pray you all, stand up.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I know you two are rival enemies:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: How comes this gentle concord in the world,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: That hatred is so far from jealousy,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To sleep by hate, and fear no enmity?

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: My lord, I shall reply amazedly,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Half sleep, half waking: but as yet, I swear,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I cannot truly say how I came here;

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: But, as I think,--for truly would I speak,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And now do I bethink me, so it is,--

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: I came with Hermia hither: our intent

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Was to be gone from Athens, where we might,

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Without the peril of the Athenian law.

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Enough, enough, my lord; you have enough:

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: I beg the law, the law, upon his head.

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: They would have stolen away; they would, Demetrius,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Thereby to have defeated you and me,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: You of your wife and me of my consent,

speaker: EGEUS
text_entry: Of my consent that she should be your wife.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: My lord, fair Helen told me of their stealth,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Of this their purpose hither to this wood;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And I in fury hither follow'd them,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Fair Helena in fancy following me.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: But, my good lord, I wot not by what power,--

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: But by some power it is,--my love to Hermia,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Melted as the snow, seems to me now

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: As the remembrance of an idle gaud

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Which in my childhood I did dote upon;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And all the faith, the virtue of my heart,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: The object and the pleasure of mine eye,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Is only Helena. To her, my lord,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Was I betroth'd ere I saw Hermia:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: But, like in sickness, did I loathe this food;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: But, as in health, come to my natural taste,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Now I do wish it, love it, long for it,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And will for evermore be true to it.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Fair lovers, you are fortunately met:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Of this discourse we more will hear anon.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Egeus, I will overbear your will;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For in the temple by and by with us

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: These couples shall eternally be knit:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And, for the morning now is something worn,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Our purposed hunting shall be set aside.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Away with us to Athens; three and three,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: We'll hold a feast in great solemnity.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Come, Hippolyta.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: These things seem small and undistinguishable,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Methinks I see these things with parted eye,

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: When every thing seems double.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: So methinks:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And I have found Demetrius like a jewel,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Mine own, and not mine own.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Are you sure

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: That we are awake? It seems to me

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: That yet we sleep, we dream. Do not you think

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: The duke was here, and bid us follow him?

speaker: HERMIA
text_entry: Yea; and my father.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And Hippolyta.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And he did bid us follow to the temple.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Why, then, we are awake: let's follow him

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And by the way let us recount our dreams.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: [Awaking]  When my cue comes, call me, and I will

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: answer: my next is, 'Most fair Pyramus.' Heigh-ho!

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Peter Quince! Flute, the bellows-mender! Snout,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: the tinker! Starveling! God's my life, stolen

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: hence, and left me asleep! I have had a most rare

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: vision. I have had a dream, past the wit of man to

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: say what dream it was: man is but an ass, if he go

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: about to expound this dream. Methought I was--there

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: is no man can tell what. Methought I was,--and

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: methought I had,--but man is but a patched fool, if

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: he will offer to say what methought I had. The eye

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: of man hath not heard, the ear of man hath not

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: seen, man's hand is not able to taste, his tongue

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: to conceive, nor his heart to report, what my dream

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: was. I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: this dream: it shall be called Bottom's Dream,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: because it hath no bottom; and I will sing it in the

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: latter end of a play, before the duke:

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: sing it at her death.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Have you sent to Bottom's house ? is he come home yet?

speaker: STARVELING
text_entry: He cannot be heard of. Out of doubt he is

speaker: STARVELING
text_entry: transported.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: If he come not, then the play is marred: it goes

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: not forward, doth it?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: It is not possible: you have not a man in all

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Athens able to discharge Pyramus but he.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: man in Athens.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Yea and the best person too; and he is a very

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: paramour for a sweet voice.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: You must say 'paragon:' a paramour is, God bless us,

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: a thing of naught.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Enter SNUG

speaker: SNUG
text_entry: Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and

speaker: SNUG
text_entry: there is two or three lords and ladies more married:

speaker: SNUG
text_entry: if our sport had gone forward, we had all been made

speaker: SNUG
text_entry: men.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: O sweet bully Bottom! Thus hath he lost sixpence a

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: day during his life; he could not have 'scaped

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: sixpence a day: an the duke had not given him

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I'll be hanged;

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: he would have deserved it: sixpence a day in

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Pyramus, or nothing.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Enter BOTTOM

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Where are these lads? where are these hearts?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Bottom! O most courageous day! O most happy hour!

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Masters, I am to discourse wonders: but ask me not

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: what; for if I tell you, I am no true Athenian. I

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: will tell you every thing, right as it fell out.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Let us hear, sweet Bottom.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Not a word of me. All that I will tell you is, that

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: the duke hath dined. Get your apparel together,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: good strings to your beards, new ribbons to your

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: pumps; meet presently at the palace; every man look

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: o'er his part; for the short and the long is, our

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: play is preferred. In any case, let Thisby have

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: clean linen; and let not him that plays the lion

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: pair his nails, for they shall hang out for the

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: lion's claws. And, most dear actors, eat no onions

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: nor garlic, for we are to utter sweet breath; and I

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: do not doubt but to hear them say, it is a sweet

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: comedy. No more words: away! go, away!

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: 'Tis strange my Theseus, that these

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: lovers speak of.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: More strange than true: I never may believe

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: These antique fables, nor these fairy toys.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Lovers and madmen have such seething brains,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: More than cool reason ever comprehends.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The lunatic, the lover and the poet

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Are of imagination all compact:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: One sees more devils than vast hell can hold,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: That is, the madman: the lover, all as frantic,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Sees Helen's beauty in a brow of Egypt:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The poet's eye, in fine frenzy rolling,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And as imagination bodies forth

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The forms of things unknown, the poet's pen

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: A local habitation and a name.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Such tricks hath strong imagination,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: That if it would but apprehend some joy,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: It comprehends some bringer of that joy;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Or in the night, imagining some fear,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: How easy is a bush supposed a bear!

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: But all the story of the night told over,

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: And all their minds transfigured so together,

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: More witnesseth than fancy's images

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: And grows to something of great constancy;

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: But, howsoever, strange and admirable.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Enter LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HERMIA, and HELENA

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Joy, gentle friends! joy and fresh days of love

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Accompany your hearts!

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: More than to us

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Wait in your royal walks, your board, your bed!

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Come now; what masques, what dances shall we have,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To wear away this long age of three hours

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Between our after-supper and bed-time?

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Where is our usual manager of mirth?

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: What revels are in hand? Is there no play,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To ease the anguish of a torturing hour?

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Call Philostrate.

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Here, mighty Theseus.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Say, what abridgement have you for this evening?

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: What masque? what music? How shall we beguile

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The lazy time, if not with some delight?

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: There is a brief how many sports are ripe:

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Make choice of which your highness will see first.

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Giving a paper

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: [Reads]  'The battle with the Centaurs, to be sung

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: By an Athenian eunuch to the harp.'

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: We'll none of that: that have I told my love,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: In glory of my kinsman Hercules.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: 'The riot of the tipsy Bacchanals,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage.'

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: That is an old device; and it was play'd

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: When I from Thebes came last a conqueror.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: 'The thrice three Muses mourning for the death

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Of Learning, late deceased in beggary.'

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: That is some satire, keen and critical,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: 'A tedious brief scene of young Pyramus

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And his love Thisbe; very tragical mirth.'

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Merry and tragical! tedious and brief!

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: That is, hot ice and wondrous strange snow.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: How shall we find the concord of this discord?

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long,

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Which is as brief as I have known a play;

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: But by ten words, my lord, it is too long,

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Which makes it tedious; for in all the play

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: There is not one word apt, one player fitted:

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: And tragical, my noble lord, it is;

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Which, when I saw rehearsed, I must confess,

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Made mine eyes water; but more merry tears

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: The passion of loud laughter never shed.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: What are they that do play it?

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Hard-handed men that work in Athens here,

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Which never labour'd in their minds till now,

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: And now have toil'd their unbreathed memories

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: With this same play, against your nuptial.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And we will hear it.

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: No, my noble lord;

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: It is not for you: I have heard it over,

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: And it is nothing, nothing in the world;

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Unless you can find sport in their intents,

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: Extremely stretch'd and conn'd with cruel pain,

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: To do you service.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I will hear that play;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: For never anything can be amiss,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: When simpleness and duty tender it.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Go, bring them in: and take your places, ladies.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Exit PHILOSTRATE

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: I love not to see wretchedness o'er charged

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: And duty in his service perishing.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: He says they can do nothing in this kind.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The kinder we, to give them thanks for nothing.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Our sport shall be to take what they mistake:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And what poor duty cannot do, noble respect

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Takes it in might, not merit.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Where I have come, great clerks have purposed

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: To greet me with premeditated welcomes;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Where I have seen them shiver and look pale,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Make periods in the midst of sentences,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Throttle their practised accent in their fears

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And in conclusion dumbly have broke off,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Not paying me a welcome. Trust me, sweet,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Out of this silence yet I pick'd a welcome;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: And in the modesty of fearful duty

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I read as much as from the rattling tongue

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Of saucy and audacious eloquence.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: In least speak most, to my capacity.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Re-enter PHILOSTRATE

speaker: PHILOSTRATE
text_entry: So please your grace, the Prologue is address'd.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Let him approach.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Flourish of trumpets

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Enter QUINCE for the Prologue

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: If we offend, it is with our good will.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: That you should think, we come not to offend,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: But with good will. To show our simple skill,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: That is the true beginning of our end.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Consider then we come but in despite.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: We do not come as minding to contest you,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Our true intent is. All for your delight

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: We are not here. That you should here repent you,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: The actors are at hand and by their show

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: You shall know all that you are like to know.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: This fellow doth not stand upon points.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt; he knows

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: not the stop. A good moral, my lord: it is not

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: enough to speak, but to speak true.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Indeed he hath played on his prologue like a child

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: on a recorder; a sound, but not in government.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: His speech, was like a tangled chain; nothing

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: impaired, but all disordered. Who is next?

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Enter Pyramus and Thisbe, Wall, Moonshine, and Lion

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Gentles, perchance you wonder at this show;

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: But wonder on, till truth make all things plain.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: This man is Pyramus, if you would know;

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: This beauteous lady Thisby is certain.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: This man, with lime and rough-cast, doth present

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Wall, that vile Wall which did these lovers sunder;

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: And through Wall's chink, poor souls, they are content

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: To whisper. At the which let no man wonder.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: This man, with lanthorn, dog, and bush of thorn,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Presenteth Moonshine; for, if you will know,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: By moonshine did these lovers think no scorn

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: To meet at Ninus' tomb, there, there to woo.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: This grisly beast, which Lion hight by name,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: The trusty Thisby, coming first by night,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Did scare away, or rather did affright;

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: And, as she fled, her mantle she did fall,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Which Lion vile with bloody mouth did stain.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Anon comes Pyramus, sweet youth and tall,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: And finds his trusty Thisby's mantle slain:

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Whereat, with blade, with bloody blameful blade,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: He bravely broach'd is boiling bloody breast;

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: And Thisby, tarrying in mulberry shade,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: His dagger drew, and died. For all the rest,

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Let Lion, Moonshine, Wall, and lovers twain

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: At large discourse, while here they do remain.

speaker: Prologue
text_entry: Exeunt Prologue, Thisbe, Lion, and Moonshine

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I wonder if the lion be to speak.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: No wonder, my lord: one lion may, when many asses do.

speaker: Wall
text_entry: In this same interlude it doth befall

speaker: Wall
text_entry: That I, one Snout by name, present a wall;

speaker: Wall
text_entry: And such a wall, as I would have you think,

speaker: Wall
text_entry: That had in it a crannied hole or chink,

speaker: Wall
text_entry: Through which the lovers, Pyramus and Thisby,

speaker: Wall
text_entry: Did whisper often very secretly.

speaker: Wall
text_entry: This loam, this rough-cast and this stone doth show

speaker: Wall
text_entry: That I am that same wall; the truth is so:

speaker: Wall
text_entry: And this the cranny is, right and sinister,

speaker: Wall
text_entry: Through which the fearful lovers are to whisper.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Would you desire lime and hair to speak better?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: discourse, my lord.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Enter Pyramus

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Pyramus draws near the wall: silence!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: O grim-look'd night! O night with hue so black!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: O night, which ever art when day is not!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: O night, O night! alack, alack, alack,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: I fear my Thisby's promise is forgot!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: And thou, O wall, O sweet, O lovely wall,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: That stand'st between her father's ground and mine!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Thou wall, O wall, O sweet and lovely wall,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Show me thy chink, to blink through with mine eyne!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Wall holds up his fingers

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Thanks, courteous wall: Jove shield thee well for this!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: But what see I? No Thisby do I see.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: O wicked wall, through whom I see no bliss!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Cursed be thy stones for thus deceiving me!

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse again.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: No, in truth, sir, he should not. 'Deceiving me'

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: is Thisby's cue: she is to enter now, and I am to

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: spy her through the wall. You shall see, it will

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: fall pat as I told you. Yonder she comes.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Enter Thisbe

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: O wall, full often hast thou heard my moans,

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: For parting my fair Pyramus and me!

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: My cherry lips have often kiss'd thy stones,

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Thy stones with lime and hair knit up in thee.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: I see a voice: now will I to the chink,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: To spy an I can hear my Thisby's face. Thisby!

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: My love thou art, my love I think.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover's grace;

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: And, like Limander, am I trusty still.

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: And I like Helen, till the Fates me kill.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Not Shafalus to Procrus was so true.

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: As Shafalus to Procrus, I to you.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: O kiss me through the hole of this vile wall!

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: I kiss the wall's hole, not your lips at all.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Wilt thou at Ninny's tomb meet me straightway?

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: 'Tide life, 'tide death, I come without delay.

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Exeunt Pyramus and Thisbe

speaker: Wall
text_entry: Thus have I, Wall, my part discharged so;

speaker: Wall
text_entry: And, being done, thus Wall away doth go.

speaker: Wall
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Now is the mural down between the two neighbours.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: No remedy, my lord, when walls are so wilful to hear

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: without warning.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The best in this kind are but shadows; and the worst

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: are no worse, if imagination amend them.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: It must be your imagination then, and not theirs.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: If we imagine no worse of them than they of

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: themselves, they may pass for excellent men. Here

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: come two noble beasts in, a man and a lion.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Enter Lion and Moonshine

speaker: Lion
text_entry: You, ladies, you, whose gentle hearts do fear

speaker: Lion
text_entry: The smallest monstrous mouse that creeps on floor,

speaker: Lion
text_entry: May now perchance both quake and tremble here,

speaker: Lion
text_entry: When lion rough in wildest rage doth roar.

speaker: Lion
text_entry: Then know that I, one Snug the joiner, am

speaker: Lion
text_entry: A lion-fell, nor else no lion's dam;

speaker: Lion
text_entry: For, if I should as lion come in strife

speaker: Lion
text_entry: Into this place, 'twere pity on my life.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: A very gentle beast, of a good conscience.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: The very best at a beast, my lord, that e'er I saw.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: This lion is a very fox for his valour.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: True; and a goose for his discretion.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Not so, my lord; for his valour cannot carry his

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: discretion; and the fox carries the goose.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: His discretion, I am sure, cannot carry his valour;

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: for the goose carries not the fox. It is well:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: leave it to his discretion, and let us listen to the moon.

speaker: Moonshine
text_entry: This lanthorn doth the horned moon present;--

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: He should have worn the horns on his head.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: He is no crescent, and his horns are

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: invisible within the circumference.

speaker: Moonshine
text_entry: This lanthorn doth the horned moon present;

speaker: Moonshine
text_entry: Myself the man i' the moon do seem to be.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: This is the greatest error of all the rest: the man

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: should be put into the lanthorn. How is it else the

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: man i' the moon?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: He dares not come there for the candle; for, you

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: see, it is already in snuff.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: I am aweary of this moon: would he would change!

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: It appears, by his small light of discretion, that

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: he is in the wane; but yet, in courtesy, in all

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: reason, we must stay the time.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Proceed, Moon.

speaker: Moonshine
text_entry: All that I have to say, is, to tell you that the

speaker: Moonshine
text_entry: lanthorn is the moon; I, the man in the moon; this

speaker: Moonshine
text_entry: thorn-bush, my thorn-bush; and this dog, my dog.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Why, all these should be in the lanthorn; for all

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: these are in the moon. But, silence! here comes Thisbe.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Enter Thisbe

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: This is old Ninny's tomb. Where is my love?

speaker: Lion
text_entry: [Roaring]  Oh--

speaker: Lion
text_entry: Thisbe runs off

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Well roared, Lion.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Well run, Thisbe.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Well shone, Moon. Truly, the moon shines with a

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: good grace.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: The Lion shakes Thisbe's mantle, and exit

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Well moused, Lion.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: And so the lion vanished.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And then came Pyramus.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Enter Pyramus

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Sweet Moon, I thank thee for thy sunny beams;

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: I thank thee, Moon, for shining now so bright;

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: For, by thy gracious, golden, glittering gleams,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: I trust to take of truest Thisby sight.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: But stay, O spite!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: But mark, poor knight,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: What dreadful dole is here!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Eyes, do you see?

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: How can it be?

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: O dainty duck! O dear!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Thy mantle good,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: What, stain'd with blood!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Approach, ye Furies fell!

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: O Fates, come, come,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Cut thread and thrum;

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Quail, crush, conclude, and quell!

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: This passion, and the death of a dear friend, would

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: go near to make a man look sad.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Beshrew my heart, but I pity the man.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame?

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Since lion vile hath here deflower'd my dear:

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Which is--no, no--which was the fairest dame

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: That lived, that loved, that liked, that look'd

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: with cheer.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Come, tears, confound;

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Out, sword, and wound

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: The pap of Pyramus;

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Ay, that left pap,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Where heart doth hop:

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Stabs himself

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Thus die I, thus, thus, thus.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Now am I dead,

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Now am I fled;

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: My soul is in the sky:

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Tongue, lose thy light;

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Moon take thy flight:

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Exit Moonshine

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Now die, die, die, die, die.

speaker: Pyramus
text_entry: Dies

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: No die, but an ace, for him; for he is but one.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: Less than an ace, man; for he is dead; he is nothing.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover, and

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: prove an ass.

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: How chance Moonshine is gone before Thisbe comes

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: back and finds her lover?

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: She will find him by starlight. Here she comes; and

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: her passion ends the play.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Re-enter Thisbe

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Methinks she should not use a long one for such a

speaker: HIPPOLYTA
text_entry: Pyramus: I hope she will be brief.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: A mote will turn the balance, which Pyramus, which

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thisbe, is the better; he for a man, God warrant us;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: she for a woman, God bless us.

speaker: LYSANDER
text_entry: She hath spied him already with those sweet eyes.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And thus she means, videlicet:--

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Asleep, my love?

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: What, dead, my dove?

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: O Pyramus, arise!

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Speak, speak. Quite dumb?

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Dead, dead? A tomb

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Must cover thy sweet eyes.

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: These My lips,

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: This cherry nose,

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: These yellow cowslip cheeks,

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Are gone, are gone:

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Lovers, make moan:

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: His eyes were green as leeks.

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: O Sisters Three,

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Come, come to me,

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: With hands as pale as milk;

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Lay them in gore,

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Since you have shore

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: With shears his thread of silk.

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Tongue, not a word:

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Come, trusty sword;

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Come, blade, my breast imbrue:

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Stabs herself

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: And, farewell, friends;

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Thus Thisby ends:

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Adieu, adieu, adieu.

speaker: Thisbe
text_entry: Dies

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Ay, and Wall too.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: [Starting up]  No assure you; the wall is down that

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: parted their fathers. Will it please you to see the

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: epilogue, or to hear a Bergomask dance between two

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: of our company?

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: No epilogue, I pray you; for your play needs no

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: excuse. Never excuse; for when the players are all

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: dead, there needs none to be blamed. Marry, if he

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: that writ it had played Pyramus and hanged himself

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: in Thisbe's garter, it would have been a fine

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: tragedy: and so it is, truly; and very notably

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: discharged. But come, your Bergomask: let your

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: epilogue alone.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: A dance

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve:

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Lovers, to bed; 'tis almost fairy time.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: I fear we shall out-sleep the coming morn

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: As much as we this night have overwatch'd.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: This palpable-gross play hath well beguiled

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: The heavy gait of night. Sweet friends, to bed.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: A fortnight hold we this solemnity,

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: In nightly revels and new jollity.

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: THESEUS
text_entry: Enter PUCK

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Now the hungry lion roars,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And the wolf behowls the moon;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Whilst the heavy ploughman snores,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: All with weary task fordone.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Now the wasted brands do glow,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Whilst the screech-owl, screeching loud,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Puts the wretch that lies in woe

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: In remembrance of a shroud.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Now it is the time of night

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: That the graves all gaping wide,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Every one lets forth his sprite,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: In the church-way paths to glide:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And we fairies, that do run

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: By the triple Hecate's team,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: From the presence of the sun,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Following darkness like a dream,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Now are frolic: not a mouse

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Shall disturb this hallow'd house:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I am sent with broom before,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: To sweep the dust behind the door.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Enter OBERON and TITANIA with their train

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Through the house give gathering light,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: By the dead and drowsy fire:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Every elf and fairy sprite

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Hop as light as bird from brier;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And this ditty, after me,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Sing, and dance it trippingly.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: First, rehearse your song by rote

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To each word a warbling note:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Hand in hand, with fairy grace,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Will we sing, and bless this place.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Song and dance

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Now, until the break of day,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Through this house each fairy stray.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: To the best bride-bed will we,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Which by us shall blessed be;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And the issue there create

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Ever shall be fortunate.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: So shall all the couples three

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Ever true in loving be;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And the blots of Nature's hand

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Shall not in their issue stand;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Never mole, hare lip, nor scar,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Nor mark prodigious, such as are

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Despised in nativity,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Shall upon their children be.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With this field-dew consecrate,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Every fairy take his gait;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And each several chamber bless,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Through this palace, with sweet peace;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And the owner of it blest

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Ever shall in safety rest.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Trip away; make no stay;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Meet me all by break of day.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Exeunt OBERON, TITANIA, and train

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: If we shadows have offended,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Think but this, and all is mended,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: That you have but slumber'd here

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: While these visions did appear.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And this weak and idle theme,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: No more yielding but a dream,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Gentles, do not reprehend:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: if you pardon, we will mend:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And, as I am an honest Puck,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: If we have unearned luck

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Now to 'scape the serpent's tongue,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: We will make amends ere long;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Else the Puck a liar call;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: So, good night unto you all.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Give me your hands, if we be friends,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And Robin shall restore amends.
